results.title: The Australian Royal Tours Collection 1901-1988
results.creator_credit: John Mandleberg, Aviva Ziegler and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A unique, visual cavalcade documenting the history of Australian tours by the British Royal Family since the turn of the century. It captures all the pomp and ceremony of the visits in the early 1900s by King George V, Edward the Prince of Wales and George VI, Queen Elizabeth’s first visit in 1954 and continues through to the younger generation of Royals with Diana and Fergie’s recent visits. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Mandleberg, Aviva Ziegler and Film Australia

results.title: Populate or perish
results.brief_description: Explores Australia’s population debate showing how after 50 years of continuous growth, new arguments about limiting Australia’s population are emerging. This program examines the post-war era when the cry to “Populate or perish” fostered Government sponsored immigration shemes, provided the applicants were white. It traces the gradual evolution of Australia as a multicultural society, primarily concentrated on the east coast.

results.title: Land of the long weekend
results.creator_credit: Sue Brooks, Susan Ardill and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australia was the first country in the world to have a 40 hour working week, which accompanied by an array of public holidays, led to the identification of Australia as the working man’s paradise, a mythical land of the long weekend. This film examines how, in the face of deregulation and restructuring, long term unemployment and 24 hour trading, Australians have structured and restructured their time. Will Australians, drunk on sunshine, rally in time to save their precious weekend - or has it, in the drive to be flexible and efficient, already been lost?

results.title: The Australian image. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: C Hunniford, N. Hildyard and Ray Edmondson
results.brief_description: Lost and Found explores the early moving images of Australia and their interdependence on our national identity. These ageing films and sound recordings can be preserved with the vital assistance of the National Film and Sound Archive. “Days When the World Was Young” looks at the representation of Australian landscape in film and it’s effect on early identity. “It’s On Record” provides a background for the history of sound recordings. “Hot from the Spot to the Screen” watch the early news events that shaped the nation captured in sound and on film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: C Hunniford, N. Hildyard and Ray Edmondson

results.title: The Australian Government System
results.creator_credit: Ian Hart, Canberra. College of Advanced Education. Media Centre and Public Service Board
results.brief_description: Provides a broad description of the Australian Government System. Addresses the legislative arm of government including the Governor General, the Senate and House of Representatives. Overviews the executive arm of Government including the Executive Council. Introduces Departments, Authorities and the Federal Judiciary including both the High Court and Family Court of Australia.

results.title: The Australian ballet: opening act 1962-1972
results.creator_credit: Michelle Potter, Sally Jackson, National Library of Australia and ScreenSound Australia
results.brief_description: It was a fortuitous evening when Harold Holt, then federal treasurer, approached Peggy van Praagh and advised her the he could provide the financial means to establish what would become Australia’s first national ballet company. The season opened in 1962 with a performance of Swan Lake at Her Majesty’s Theatre in Sydney and featured 40 dancers, chiefly comprised from the Borovansky ballet company, that van Praagh took over on the death of its titular founder. The company toured Australia, introducing delighted audiences to the classics, innovative pieces and new choreography including Melbourne Cup, and The Display and Yugen by Sir Robert Helpmann who would later join van Praagh as co-artistic director. Helpmann and van Praag represented two sides of the artistic coin - Helpmann a flamboyant promoter of the ballet without being actively involved in the day to day running, and van Praag, the English teacher and educator who maintained a strong bond between the company and her mother country. Introduced by Barry Kitcher and narrated by Helen Vaughan Roberts, this program presents archival footage of performances, highlights of international guests such as Sonia Arova, Erik Bruhn, Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, original pieces from the 1950s, biographical information about Helpmann and van Praag and profiles Australian artists including Marilyn Rowe and Kelvin Coe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michelle Potter, Sally Jackson, National Library of Australia and ScreenSound Australia

results.title: The Astronomers. Eps. 1-3
results.creator_credit: David Oyster, James F. Golway, Julio Moline and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description: A series which looks at the research projects of individual astronomers, and the process of astronomy. “Where is the rest of the universe?” looks at the work of three astronomers: Vera Rubin and Tony Tyson who are conducting separate research projects into dark matter, which astronomers believe makes up 90% of the known universe and Frank Dobson, inventor of a home-made telescope, who preaches the gospel of astronomy to anyone who will listen. “Searching for black holes” looks in detail at an experiment linking several radio telescopes worldwide in an attempt to discover if there is a black hole at the heart of a quasar-like galaxy NGC1275. “A Window to creation” looks at background radiation from the big bang and the attempt to explain how the smoothness of the primeval universe developed into the complex universe we now can see. Narrated by Richard Chamberlain.

results.title: The Astonishing Ashtons
results.creator_credit: Lisa Jane Wallace, John Moore and John Moore Productions
results.brief_description: For 150 years Ashton’s Circus has criss-crossed Australia, battling floods, high winds and outback roads to bring the magic of the circus to rural and city dwellers alike. This documentary goes behind the greasepaint and spectacle of the circus to provide an insight into the lives of the circus performers and other personnel.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lisa Jane Wallace, John Moore and John Moore Productions

results.title: The Astronaut
results.creator_credit: Peter Charley, Alan Hall, Beyond Productions and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: In 1998 the Space Shuttle “Endeavour” left Earth with a crew of seven - six American astronauts and one Russian cosmonaut to join the aging space shuttle Mir. On board was astronaut Andy Thomas, a space engineer born in Australia who trained in Russia to prepare for the mission. His stay on Mir would be for 4 1/2 months and his main function was to be the subject of research on the psychological and physiological effects of being in space. This research was used in developing the International Space Station Program; 15 nations working together to construct a permanently occupied laboratory in space.
